title: Mom and Pop Buck Trend to Snap Up Physical Gold
text:

Wed, Aug 5, 2015, 11:24 BST - UK Markets close in 5 hrs 6 mins Mom and Pop Buck Trend to Snap Up Physical Gold The Wall Street Journal – 13 minutes ago Print ‘Mom and pop’ investors are back in the business of buying physical gold. 
Gold prices tanked in July, but the U.S. Mint had its best month for gold coin sales in two years, while a U.K. bullion trading website reported a surge in buying. 
“Private investors … view gold as financial insurance, even the price drop in July doesn’t undo that. If anything it kind of proves the case: … it’s not paying out when you don’t need it to,” said Adrian Ash, head of research at BullionVault, a U.K. online platform for trading physical gold and silver. 
Gold prices shed nearly 6% by the end of last month after the precious metal tumbled to a five-and-a-half-year low at $1,077.40 a troy ounce on July 24. 
But searches for ‘buy gold’ have jumped almost 30% since June, according to Google Trends data, and are approaching levels not seen since April 2013. 
The U.S. Mint reported a jump in gold coin purchases. It sold 170,000 ounces of American Eagle gold coins in July, the largest volume for a single month since April 2013. 
BullionVault said July 24 was its heaviest day’s trading since October 2014, and one of its best days ever for opening new accounts. 
This wave of gold-buying by retail investors runs counter to the broader trend, in which many other types of investors are rushing to jettison their gold investments. 
The largest gold Exchange-Traded Fund, SPDR, saw outflows of $263 million in the week to August 3. Analysts said this is a different phenomenon: ETF investors are looking for financial returns and not physical investments, and are quicker to ditch their holdings when the price tanks.
